body:
Thank you for the detailed report! A regression from 10.1.6 to 10.2.0 is a bit surprising because there have been no HTTP-related changes in there beyond ignore_domains, which is not used here. I'm unfortunately unable to reproduce your original issue on Linux.

Can you reproduce with `--set proxy_debug -vvv` and (if yes) share the log here? Thanks!

I can indeed reproduce it with the proxy_debug.

For sake of completeness, I attach the logs for running the same command apt-get update in 10.1.6, 10.2.0, and 10.3.1.  

From what I can see, there is only one connection being made and it seems multiple calls are made over this connection, could that be a problem?
[logs_10.1.6.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16278778/logs_10.1.6.txt)
[logs_10.2.0.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16278779/logs_10.2.0.txt)
[logs_10.3.1.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16278780/logs_10.3.1.txt)


If I need to test anything else, happy to run additional tests

For all three tests, I let it run all the way till the end (i.e. till apt-get update is completely finished).

Maybe also useful, this is the output of pip list for the 10.3.1 environment:
```

```

This is the output for the 10.1.6 environment:
```

----------------- ----------

```

I am using anaconda, but only to create separate environments with python=3.12.4 installed, all other installations were done via pip

Thank you for the super detailed logs! üç∞ 

The failing log you posted should be perfect in theory, but I've tried to build two different test cases now based on that and still can't reproduce it. Can I ask you to do the following two things:

1. Record a PCAP capture with Wireshark during your test run (this may require to captures, one for loopback and one for your outgoing interface).
2. Replace the `assert` statement in `mitmproxy\proxy\layers\http\_http1.py", line 353` with the following:

```python
        assert self.stream_id == event.stream_id, f"{self.stream_id=} {event.stream_id=} {event.stream_id=} {self.request_done=} {self.response_done=} {self=} {len(self.buf)=}"
```

This should hopefully give more clues on what's happening here. Thanks!

Ok, with a bit of a delay, was all day out yesterday, here the requested items. I included the verbose log again (with line 353 assertion statement being changed).

Also ran two simultaneous tcpdump instances, one for the port http outside and one for the port 7070 on loopback interface lo (where the proxy is listening)

[mitmproxy_log_10.3.1.log](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16319989/mitmproxy_log_10.3.1.log)
[dump_port_80.pcap.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16319995/dump_port_80.pcap.zip)
[dump_port_7070.pcap.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16319996/dump_port_7070.pcap.zip)

If you need me to run anything else, please let me know!

issue.title: Guard server_event against reentrancy, fix #7027

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
#### Description

This fixes a really gnarly bug that turned up in https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/issues/7027.

#### Checklist

 - [x] I have updated tests where applicable.
 - [x] I have added an entry to the CHANGELOG.

body: Thank you so much for the detailed logs! This was incredibly useful. I finally managed to repro things and track down the root cause. #7031 has a fix!

Awesome! thanks for taking the time to investigate!

Now that you found the problem, was it related to the change between 10.1.6 and 10.2.0 or was that just coincedence that now it got triggered more easily?

Or was the 10.1.6 for me the same as what you were experiencing on your computer, just could not reproduce it?

This was introduced in https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/pull/6557/commits/0bb8298a23d8644cc2e04aa5ededb2345fe3717b, which indeed first made it into 10.2.0. :)

I still didn't manage to repro it with apt, but the last log had the final clue to get me on the right track: We were crashing with `self.response_done=False`, which means that 

https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/blob/f45d6e970b05935e311b3a63e28261ea494f7105/mitmproxy/proxy/layers/http/_http1.py#L119

was not executed yet. But we also see
```
[13:43:57.805][127.0.0.1:57442]       << Receive(RequestEndOfMessage(stream_id=7))
```
in the logs from
https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/blob/f45d6e970b05935e311b3a63e28261ea494f7105/mitmproxy/proxy/layers/http/_http1.py#L117

just two lines above. So there _must_ be some sort of race. That was very confusing as we spent a lot of effort to make sure the proxy core is _not_ multi-threaded (https://mitmproxy.org/posts/new-proxy-core/). So these issues shouldn't exist by design. üòÖ

Looking closer at the logs I found that we're starting to handle a second event in the middle of handling the first one. And I eventually realized that this happens because eager task execution kind of acts like an `await` as it pauses the current method to first execute a different task. I then built the test in #7031 to validate my assumptions and implemented a fix. :)

Thank you again for the fantastic logs! üç∞

For sake of completeness, I just installed the mitmproxy from your branch with the fix  in a brand new environment and tested it a couple of times and I can confirm that with this new version I am not able to reproduce the problem anymore!
Another question I have is when do you currently plan to have a release of mitmproxy that contains this fix?
No fixed timeline yet, at some point in the next two months. Would a faster new release with the fix make your life significantly easier?

It would make it easier in the way that I could release a new version of my switcher app such that less of my users will be affected by the assertion error as I don't have a way to switch back to 10.1.6 due to the fact no binary wheels exist for some dependencies for python 3.12 (which is something I can unfortunately not change due to the policies on the laptops)
